block.p: Around Town
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., ''Living in America: The Allure of Gold,'' the first of three events in conjunction with the exhibition, featuring a crafts fair, the Mexican dance troupe Atl-Tlachinolli, a panel discussion and the Andean music group Tahuantinsuyo. Through May 28, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a display with hundreds of butterflies in a re-creation of their natural habitat. In the Imax theater, ''Roving Mars,'' a film about NASA's Mars Rover. Timed tickets to ''Gold'' and ''The Butterfly Conservatory,'' which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for 12 and younger. Imax tickets, which include museum admission, are $21; $16 for students and 60+; $12 for children under 12. Suggested museum admission: $14; $10.50 for students and 60+; children, $8. Combination tickets, including museum and Rose Center admission and the Hayden Planetarium space show (''Cosmic Collisions''): $22; $16.50 for students and 60+; $13 for 12 and younger; under 2, free; admission that includes all activities: $30; $23 for students and 60+; $19 for 12 and younger. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. (to 8:45 p.m. on Fridays). (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200; amnh.org.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. Through Sept. 3, ''New York Divided: Slavery and the Civil War,'' a display of historical documents, photographs, political cartoons and other items. Thursday at 6:30 p.m., a discussion with Thomas Brothers, author of ''Louis Armstrong's New Orleans''; $15; $10 for students, educators and 65+; $8 for members. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; to 8 p.m. on Fridays. $10; $7 for educators and 65+; $6 for students; free for those under 12. (212) 873-3400; nyhistory.org.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. Monday at 11 a.m. and 2:30 p.m., performances of spirituals by the Great Day Chorale in celebration of Martin Luther King's Birthday; also a tour at 1 p.m. of the plants of Africa. Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. $5; $3 for students and 65+; free for children under 16. Through Feb. 28, free admission Tuesdays through Fridays and Saturdays from 10 a.m. to noon. (718) 623-7200; bbg.org.

WAVE HILL, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx. Though Sunday, ''Celebrating Winter Through Nature,'' a holiday installation by 11 artists, with related performances, art projects and other activities. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a garden demonstration in growing moth orchids. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Bits of Cloth and Lots of Freedom,'' a family art project based on African-American quilts with the theme of freedom. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. $4; $2 for students and 65+; free, under 6; Tuesdays, free all day; Saturdays, free 9 a.m. to noon. (718) 549-3200.
Events

ANNUAL BROOKLYN TRIBUTE TO DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, near Ashland Place, Fort Greene. Monday at 10:30 a.m., with gospel music, an art exhibit and a screening of ''American Blackout,'' a 2006 documentary about black voters by Ian Inaba. Free tickets available beginning at 9 a.m. (718) 636-4100.

22nd BALKAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL, at two Manhattan locations. Tonight at 7:30, a dance party and workshop with music at the Jan Hus Church and Neighborhood House, 351 East 74th Street; $17; $13 for students; $6, 6 to 12; free, under 6. Tomorrow night, beginning at 6 and continuing through early Sunday morning, performances by more than 40 bands and choral groups at Good Shepherd School, 620 Isham Street, Inwood; $32, $22, $10, and free, under 6. Sponsored by the Zlatne Uste Balkan Brass Band. zlatneuste.org.

TOLERANCE AND DIVERSITY EXHIBITIONS, New York Tolerance Center, 226 East 42nd Street, Manhattan. Monday at 9:30 a.m., noon and 3 p.m., guided, interactive tours and film and theater presentations that focus on civil rights, genocide, freedom of speech and conflict resolution. The Center, which offers diversity training for educational and law enforcement groups, is usually open to visits by groups only and not individuals. Reservations required: (212) 697-1180. $20; $15, children 12 and older and 65+.
Spoken Word

A 50TH ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION OF THE BEATS, 92nd Street Y, Poetry Center, 1395 Lexington Avenue. Monday at 8 p.m., with readings and recordings in celebration of Allen Ginsberg's ''Howl'' and Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road,'' with Laurie Anderson, the performance artist and others. $18 ($10 for those 35 and younger). (212) 415-5500.

SECOND SUNDAYS, Noguchi Museum, 9-01 33rd Road, at Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens. Sunday at 3 p.m., readings of poetry by Yonejiro Noguchi, father of the artist Isamu Noguchi, and others. Free with admission: $10; $5 for students; free, under 12. (718) 204-7088.

DOWNTOWN THIRD THURSDAYS 2007, a free, lecture series devoted to issues relating to Lower Manhattan at various locations. Thursday night at 7, at 7 World Trade Center, Vesey and Greenwich Streets, 52nd floor, ''Think New York: A Ground Zero Diary,'' with the architect Rafael Viñoly. Sponsored by the Downtown Alliance. Reservations required: downtownny.com/thirdthursdays.

'AMERICAN MEDICI: THE KRESS BROTHERS,' Metropolitan Museum of Art. Thursday night at 8, a lecture on the Samuel H. Kress Collection, an extensive art collection, by Jocelyn Kress, the niece of Samuel H. Kress. $22. (212) 570-3949.

VISUAL ECHO, Center for Architecture, 536 La Guardia Place, near Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 358-6133. Today at 5:30 p.m., Jason Bruges will speak about his interactive light installation, up through March 10. Free.

'VIDA SECRETA, PALABRA OCULTA: DALí AS WRITER,' Instituto Cervantes, 211-215 East 49th Street, Manhattan. Today, 3 to 10 p.m., a free symposium on the artist Salvador Dalí, in English and Spanish. (212) 308-7720.

BROOKLYN BREWERIES, Salt Marsh Nature Center, Marine Park, East 33rd Street and Avenue U, Brooklyn. Sunday at 1 p.m., a discussion with the Urban Park Rangers and members of the Salt Marsh Nature Center History Club. Free. Call 311.
Walking Tours

OUTDOORS CLUB Sunday at 11 a.m., a walk through the Queens neighborhood of Ridgewood-Glendale, meeting in Manhattan on the southeast corner of Lexington and 42nd Street. $3; participants should also take along an unlimited MetroCard. (718) 784-3643.

MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''More Than Tall: Midtown Rises,'' a skyscraper tour of Midtown Manhattan, , meeting on the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 43rd Street.$15; $12 for members. (212) 935-3960.
TIMELINE TOURING: 'A LIVING HISTORY TOUR OF THE LOWER EAST SIDE,' Sunday at 1:15 p.m. $38; $32 for children. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 209-3370 or timelinetouring.com.

SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM, 12 Fulton Street, Lower Manhattan. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a Seaport tour; free with museum admission. Monday at 10 a.m., ''African-American Life in Lower Manhattan,'' a walking tour and discussion; $12; $8 for children; $4 for members. Museum admission: $8; $6 for students; $4 for children five to 12; free for children under five. Both meet at the museum. (212) 748-8600.

BIG ONION WALKING TOURS Monday at 1 p.m., ''Martin Luther King, Jr. Day in Historic Harlem,'' meeting on the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. $15; $12 for 63+; $10 for students and New-York Historical Society members. (212) 439-1090.

WALKABOUT NEW YORK Tomorrow at 11 a.m., a tour of the financial district, meeting at the main gate to City Hall Park, Broadway and Park Row. $15; $45 with a optional post-tour lunch at Fraunces Tavern. (718) 789-7291.

SHOREWALKERS Tomorrow at 11 a.m., ''Over and Under Three Bridges of Brooklyn,'' features a walk from Manhattan to Brooklyn neighborhoods near the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges, meeting in Manhattan in front of the Municipal Building, near the entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge. $3. (212) 663-2167.

MEATPACKING DISTRICT MEANDER Tomorrow at 2:30 p.m., stops at an art gallery, a pub and a clothing store, meeting on the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and 14th Street. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. $5. (212) 265-2663.

GHOSTS OF THE AFRICAN BURIAL GROUND AND DOWNTOWN Tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., a Lower Manhattan tour led by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks, meeting at Blimpies Restaurant, 38 Park Row. $15. (888) 377-4455.

STREET SMARTS N.Y. Tomorrow: at 2 p.m., ''Stanford White -- Splendor and Scandal'' visits buildings designed by the architect; at 6 p.m., ''Ghostly Greenwich Village.'' Both meet at the Washington Arch. $10. (212) 969-8262.

'HELL'S KITCHEN-A-POPPIN; THEN AND NOW,' Sunday at 11 a.m., the residential, business and theatrical histories of the area, meeting on the northwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 59th Street. Sponsored by Bonnie's Lost New York Walks and Talks. $15. (212) 594-8039.
Around Town
